thoughts.a: The input and output grids are the same size. The input grid contains an overlapping set of different colors of gridded layers. There seems to be a blue grid of vertical and horizontal single tile wide lines on top of red grid of vertical and horizontal thicker lines, sometimes more than one tile wide. Both of these grids are on top of a black color background. Additionally, in the input grid, some of the subsections have been labeled with aqua color instead of red or blue or the black background color. We notice that the output grid is nearly the same as the input grid, with nearly all the tiles the same colors located in the same locations, with the exception of additional tiles labeled with the aqua tile. Why are these specific tiles colored aqua? The aqua shapes in the input grid was a 1x2 and a 2x1 rectangle shape, on what would have otherwise been the red grid. The aqua shapes that are present in the output grid are all the instances of these two rectangle shapes that were originally red in the input grid. Thus the output grid has labeled all of the instances of this shaped object instead of just the ones initially labeled in the input grid with the aqua color. Thus the hypothesis is the following. The input and output grids will both contain two sets of overlapping grids made up of different colors on top of a black color background. Some objects with some shape or shapes will be labeled or colored with aqua in the input grid. In order to construct the output grid, we need to copy over the input grid exactly as is, but identify and then color with aqua all the instances of objects with this exact shape. Note that the objects of that shape that was are looking for can only exist in the color of the tiles that it originally would have been in the input grid. In this case, the aqua tiles had replaced red tiles, so we should only look for equivalent shaped objects of that color to change to aqua in the output grid.
thoughts.b: The input grid again contains two overlapping sets of different colors of gridded layers. In this case it looks like red horizontal and vertical lines form a grid on top of blue horizontal and vertical lines, both of which lay on top of a black color background. According to the hypothesis, somewhere in the input grid, there will be an aqua-colored object or objects. In this case, we see an aqua colored plus sign, whose original color would have been blue. In order to construct the output grid, we copy over the input grid exactly as is, with the exception of identifying and then coloring all of the instances of this aqua shaped object. In this case, we need to look only at the blue colored shapes, and identify all of the blue objects that are exactly a plus sign. we see that there are three blue plus shaped objects in the input grid, and thus these three blue shaped objects will need to be colored aqua instead in the output grid. The rest of the output grid is copied exactly as is. Because this is what we see in the output grid, the hypothesis holds.
thoughts.c: Input grid again contains two overlapping sets of different colors of gridded layers. In this case, it looks like the blue gridded layer is overlapping on top of a red layer, which is on top of a black color background. According to the hypothesis, somewhere in the input grid there will be some number of aquacolored objects. In this case, we see an aqua coloredobject that is three tiles wide and one tile high, and then also an aqua object that is a plus sign with the center missing. Both of these aqua colored objects' original color would have been red. In order to construct the output grid, we copy over the input grid exactly as is, with the exception of identifying and then coloring all of the instances of these aqua-shaped objects. In this case, we need to look for two different shapes. Identify exactly one additional red 3 tile wide horizontal line near the bottom left of the input grid. These tiles need to be aqua in the output grid. For the other shape, we identify three additional red plus sign objects with their centers missing. Each of these instances also needs to be colored aqua in the output grid. Because this is exactly what we see in the output grid, the hypothesis holds.
thoughts.d: We apply the hypothesis here. Input and output grids should be the same size. The input grid has two overlapping sets of gridded layers. In this case it looks like a blue colored layer is on top of a red layer, which are both on top of a black color background. According to the hypothesis, there should be some number of objects that have been colored aqua. In this case, we see two such objects that are colored aqua and note that their original colors had then not been colored aqua woudl be red. In order to construct the output grid, we need to copy over the input grid as is with the exception of identifying and coloring as aqua all of the other instances of the objects that were colored aqua in the input grid. In this case, we have two such objects. One object is a 2x2 square with the top left tile missing, and the other object is a 2x2 square with the bottom right tile missing. Note that we are not allowed to rotate or otherwise transform these objects. We need to identify the locations of the exact shapes of the additional instances in the input grid, and specifically red colored instances. For the first object, we see three additional instances. For the second object we also see three additional red object instances. When constructing the output grid, we need to make sure that these identified instances of these red shapes in the input grid will be changed to aqua color in the output grid, and otherwise the output grid is exactly the same as the input grid.
